prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for taking my 3yo out to do something fun whilst my partner is at work?
I will try and keep this short . 

Almost every weekend when I say lets take our kid out to the play centre or a farm ect I get one of maybe 3  excuses every time without fail . Either "I dont want to go out / I just wanna sit and play on the computer. " " ive been at work im tired I don't wanna go out / drive " or " I don't wanna spend the money on x, y ,z" ( we have money so its not like thats a real problem )   

Today a friend asked me if i wanted to go with her with the kids to the farm near us tomorrow and I said yes . I figured since we hadn't taken little one anywhere fun for a few weeks it would be nice . 

So I mentioned it to my partner and he goes off on one about how its not fair as he is at work and he would like to go blah blah . I said so I cant take her anywhere when you're at work ? Pointed out that I asked to go not a week or two earlier and was told no its too expencive and  I dont want to go out I'm tired. ( its £7 each ). 

So now he wants me to cancle with my friend so he can go another day . I said we can go whenever you want . But apparently thats not an option either . 

Its a childrens petting zoo ffs its not like im going to see a movie wothout him. 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the scenario is in the wrong. The situation involves a parent taking their 3-year-old to a fun activity while the partner is at work. The partner has been making excuses not to go out on weekends, but when the parent decides to go without them, the partner gets upset.

First, I need to consider the dynamics here. The parent is trying to spend quality time with their child, which is important. The partner has consistently been uninterested in these outings, giving reasons like being tired, not wanting to spend money, or not feeling like going out. The parent then makes a separate plan with a friend to take the child to a farm, which the partner objects to because they're at work and want to go. The parent argues that they've been told no before for similar reasons, and the cost isn't an issue. The partner now wants to cancel the plan so they can go another day.

The key points here are about shared responsibilities in parenting and mutual respect. The parent isn't doing anything that's harmful; they're taking the child out for a legitimate activity. The partner's reaction seems to stem from feeling left out or not being included. However, the parent has already been offered excuses in the past, so maybe the partner isn't contributing as much as they should to their shared parenting duties. 

The cost isn't a real issue, so the partner's previous excuses about money are invalid. The parent is making a good choice to engage the child in an activity, which is beneficial for the child's development and the parent's own well-being. The partner's demand to cancel the plan might be about control or feeling neglected, but the parent is within their rights to make such plans independently. 

However, there's also an aspect of communication. The parent could have discussed the plan more thoroughly with the partner beforehand, even if they knew the partner might object. But given the partner's history of not wanting to go out, the parent might have felt justified in taking the initiative. 

In terms of fairness, both parents should share the responsibility of taking the child out. If the partner is only objecting when they can't go, that might indicate a need for the parent to address the partner's feelings about being excluded. But the parent isn't wrong for taking the child out when the partner isn't available. The partner needs to be more involved or communicate their needs better. 

So, considering all this, the parent isn't in the wrong. They're making an effort for the child's benefit, and the partner's reaction is more about their own feelings than the actual activity. The answer should be B (Not in the wrong).
